citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
When the inspector called the licensee to announce their presence for an unannounced inspection, the licensee stated
they were exhibiting at a county fair out of state. The licensee failed to provide an itinerary for animals in travel status and
locations of exhibition to the Deputy Administrator. Failure to provide an itinerary at least two days in advance of overnight
travel to any location other than the approved home site results in the Department's inability to conduct an inspection to
ensure the welfare of the animals covered under the Animal Welfare Act.
Any person who is subject to the Animal Welfare regulations and intends to exhibit any animal at any location other than
the approved site, shall submit a written itinerary to the Deputy Administrator. The itinerary shall include all information
required in this section, but not limited to, the names, dates, and locations (with addresses) where the animals will travel,
be housed, and be exhibited, including all anticipated dates and locations (with addresses) for any stops and layovers that
allow or require removal of the animals from the transport enclosures.
Correct from this date forward of 01 May 2025.

Last review of the contingency was over a year ago on 09 April 2024. Failure to conduct annual contingency plan reviews
reduces the capability for disaster response and may impact animal welfare in the event of emergencies. The facility must
ensure that the contingency plan is reviewed annually and that this review is documented. Additionally, this
documentation must be available to APHIS upon request.
Correct by 30 May 2025.

The indoor primary enclosure for 2 hyacinth macaws, 1 umbrella cockatoo, and 1 palm cockatoo has exposed foam
insulation on the upper walls and ceiling due to maintenance activity by the facility. The birds have direct access to the
insulation and there is evidence that one or more birds is chewing and picking at this surface due to a pile of half inch
chunks of insulation on the ground in one corner of the enclosure. Damaged interior surfaces of enclosures cannot be
easily cleaned or sanitized and insulation material may not be safe for birds. The surfaces of housing facilities must be
constructed in a manner and made of materials that allow them to be readily cleaned and/or sanitized, or removed and
replaced when worn or soiled.
Correct by 15 May 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.126(c) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
When the inspector called the licensee to announce their presence for an unannounced inspection, the licensee stated 
they were exhibiting at a county fair out of state. The licensee failed to provide an itinerary for animals in travel status and 
locations of exhibition to the Deputy Administrator. Failure to provide an itinerary at least two days in advance of overnight 
travel to any location other than the approved home site results in the Department's inability to conduct an inspection to 
ensure the welfare of the animals covered under the Animal Welfare Act. 
 
Any person who is subject to the Animal Welfare regulations and intends to exhibit any animal at any location other than 
the approved site, shall submit a written itinerary to the Deputy Administrator. The itinerary shall include all information 
required in this section, but not limited to, the names, dates, and locations (with addresses) where the animals will travel, 
be housed, and be exhibited, including all anticipated dates and locations (with addresses) for any stops and layovers that 
allow or require removal of the animals from the transport enclosures. 
 
Correct from this date forward of 01 May 2025. 
2.134(b) 
   
Contingency planning. 
Last review of the contingency was over a year ago on 09 April 2024. Failure to conduct annual contingency plan reviews 
reduces the capability for disaster response and may impact animal welfare in the event of emergencies. The facility must 
ensure that the contingency plan is reviewed annually and that this review is documented. Additionally, this 
documentation must be available to APHIS upon request.  
 
Correct by 30 May 2025. 
3.150(c) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The indoor primary enclosure for 2 hyacinth macaws, 1 umbrella cockatoo, and 1 palm cockatoo has exposed foam 
insulation on the upper walls and ceiling due to maintenance activity by the facility. The birds have direct access to the

insulation and there is evidence that one or more birds is chewing and picking at this surface due to a pile of half inch 
chunks of insulation on the ground in one corner of the enclosure. Damaged interior surfaces of enclosures cannot be 
easily cleaned or sanitized and insulation material may not be safe for birds. The surfaces of housing facilities must be 
constructed in a manner and made of materials that allow them to be readily cleaned and/or sanitized, or removed and 
replaced when worn or soiled. 
 
Correct by 15 May 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
